pynq.tests package¶

Submodules¶

pynq.tests.test_gpio module¶

pynq.tests.test_gpio.test_gpio()[source]¶

Test whether the GPIO class is working properly.

Note

The gpio_min is the GPIO base pin number + minimum user pin The gpio_max is the smallest power of 2 greater than the GPIO base.

pynq.tests.test_mmio module¶

pynq.tests.test_mmio.test_mmio()[source]¶

Test whether MMIO class is working properly.

Generate random tests to swipe through the entire range: >>> mmio.write(all offsets, random data)

Steps: 1. Initialize an instance with length in bytes 2. Write an integer to a given offset. 3. Write a number within the range [0, 2^32-1] into a 4-byte location. 4. Change to the next offset and repeat.

pynq.tests.test_pl module¶

pynq.tests.test_pl.test_end()[source]¶

Wrapping up by changing the overlay back.

This is the last test to be performed.

pynq.tests.test_pl.test_overlay()[source]¶

Test whether the overlay is properly set.

Each overlay has its own bitstream. Also need the corresponding ”.tcl” files to pass the tests.

The entries in Microblaze dictionary use the following format: mb_instance[key] = {base address, program, gpio pin}.

pynq.tests.test_pl.test_overlay1()[source]¶

Download the bitstream for the first overlay, and then test.

Need the corresponding *.tcl file to pass the tests.

pynq.tests.test_pl.test_overlay2()[source]¶

Change to another overlay, and then test.

Need the corresponding *.tcl file to pass the tests.

pynq.tests.test_su module¶

pynq.tests.test_su.test_superuser()[source]¶

Test whether the user have the root privilege.

Note

To pass all of the pytests, need the root access.

pynq.tests.util module¶

pynq.tests.util.user_answer_no(text)[source]¶
pynq.tests.util.user_answer_yes(text)[source]¶
